The course of instruction pursued at this SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and most OF u,'c
ornamental branches of female education' inc
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading, writ
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar hhe'oric'
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts; Construction of maps; use oi the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry; Elements OF Moral
Science.


ITeekIy Exercises. s.-Biblical Rccitations; Evi'
dences Of Christianity; Letter Writing, and oth
or srccies of Composition; Itecapitulatlons.


1erms.-Board and tuition, in any OF the fore

in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, Sl2, French, by one of the best masters,
&c per quarter Moderate extra charges fol
Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention IS PAID mol
only to the manners of the young ladies, but IL
their moral and religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted TO such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dams approve. Exercise and recreation, being
essential to the preservation of health and o
mental energy, occupy the intervals Of time no
devoted to study. The institution, in all ITS de
partlnents, is conducted in manner which i
is hoped, will meet the cntire appreciation OF it
patrons.

and fifteen and the thirteenth of November of
the same year, upon any vessel belonging TO cit
izens of the City of IIamburgh, and their Car
goes; and that the same be paid out of any mon
ey in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated

think proper, in opening and repairing such
road; and, for defraying the expenses thereof,

propriated.


SEC. 3. .dnd be it further enacted, That

er, near st. Augustine; and that the further

pleting the road from Colerain, in Georgia to
Tampa Bay, in the Territory of Florida, and the
appropriations aforesaid shall be paid out of any
money in the Treasury and not otherwise appro
priated

main unexpended, it shall be appropriated tc

GENERAL REGISTER
Dry Good Merchants.

Mr.. Eesseudeu-It is curious, but not
entirely novel case, that the discovery of the
effect Of rird,ing fruit trees in forcing them
into early bearing has been recently claimed
as a new achievement, fer an English,
German. and French horticulturist. Yet
in truth, it was as we'll known to the cele.
brated Button as to any modern cultivator


He was induced to make extensive expe-
riments on the decoration of forest trees prior
to their being felled, with view to ascer-
tain the comparative strength and durabill-
sy of timber cut with the bark on, and that
from which the bark had been removed some
years previously to its being felled. lie
found the strength of the wood OF trees
whose bark had been previously removed
year or two before its being cut, much great
er than that of trees felled with the bark on.
And he found. moreover, that trees win
live from one to four years after the whole
bark has been removed. He then tried
pirdkinr of fruit trees, and the following
sketch from his works will show, that he,
n completely and satisfactorily tested the
effects of it, as any modern cultivator has
done. II have made, (says the Comte de
Bufon,) many experiments upon variety
Of fruit trees. 1t is a certain or intAllible
mode of Fastening the period Of bearing,-
They (the girdled trees) blossom sometimes
three weeks before others, and give earlier
fruit, and equally good the first year. have
even had fruit on pear tree from which
had removed not only the bark but all the
SAT- svoed (alburnum) and these premature
fruits were is good as those OF other trees.
have also removed the 7Yhoie bark from
top to bottom of large apple trees and vigo-
rous plumb trees. This operation has de-
stroyed, even after the first year, the small
est of these trees, but the large ones have
sometimes resisted the effects of this bark
ing for two or three years. They were COW
cred earlier than other trees with prodi-
gious quantity of flowers, but the fruit which
succeeded, never ripened, nor even attained
any considerable size.


availed myself (says Buffon) of the expe-
rience, and of the knowledge, which these
various trials afforded me to attempt to
force into fruit trees of vigorous growth
which seemed to throw all their force


into the production of wood made my
first experiment on ounce tree re-
moved the bark in a spiral form from tive
branches of this tree. These two branches
alone gave fruit---the others remained bar
rem. Instead of removing the bark, some
times simply tied cord round a branch
the effect was the same, had the pleasure
of gathering the fruits of trees which hat
been long barren.


In what manner soever you interrupt ol
intercept the sap, you are sure OF Fastening
production of fruits, and especially of flow
ers."

The introduction OF the potatoe plant into
France, received, for more than two ccntu-
rles, an unexampled opposition from vulgar
prejudice; and it wasnot until Louis XIV who
wore branch Of the flowers of the potatoe
in the midst of the court, on day of testiv-
ity, that the people for the first time yielded
through fashion to acknowledge its value.

Tohrese,7e Potatoes.---Mr. Roberts has
taken out patent tor the following method
of keeping potatoes, carrots, and other veg
ctables, in the warmest climates for con-
siderable time:


"Take the potatoes, or other vegetables,
when thoroughly ripe, and before they have
grown In the spring, cut out with kniie
the germs or eyes, or destroy them. The
more they are kept from the air, the finer
they will be.

cultivated, Amongst the number are upwards
of 400 Camellias of II varieties, 600 Cape Jas
mines of several varieties, Green and Bohea lea
Trees, White Moss Roses, Tea Scented Hoses,
&c.


The GRAPE VINES are particularly deserv
ing the attention of the public, as the collection
Includes nearly all the finest Grapes of France
and Germany, that will stand this climate, with
number of fine Hungarian Grapes from Tokay,
imported for the subscriber, and which produced,
last season, the most delicious fruit, they are per
fcctly hardy, and bear wei


Cuttings of the Bland or poval Grape Vino
and of The fine Wine Grape, called Alexander or
ScuuYLKILL MrscApEL (also called SrnIsoMILL
CoSsrAsrIA) for sale at fifty cents per dozen,
two dollars per hundred, or fifteen dollars per
1000.


Tie Apple Trees and GroFs Pines are equal IN
guahty to any impaired from the Long Island Nnr-
series, and are sold one third cheaper than The pri'
ccS charged by those Nurseries.
| Catalogues may be had at either OF the follow.
ing places, vis:-Alderman G. Bartram's, No Ga
South Second Street; Thomas Lloyds corner OF

49, opposite Decatur street, or at stall, No. 8,
New Market, below Pine streets; at either o.
which places orders may be left and all orders
per mail, or otherwise, will be promptly attend
cd TO- and the articles delivered III Philadelphia
or shipped 10 order.


Strangers visiting Philadelphia, are respect
fully invited TO view the Garden, which is stllat
ed on the west bank of The Schlylkill, half
nile below Gray's Ferry, A miles nom the Cen
tire Square.


ROBERT CARR.

full articles.headline:
Young Ladies Boarding School,

Mr A1INcroN. DELAWARE.
full articles.article:
AT WlLMINGION, DELLA " 'NH'


Under the superintendent and instruction OF
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted BY accomplished
female teachers. 49,.


The course of instruction pursued at this SEM
mary, comprises all the useful, and most OF u,'c
ornamental branches of female education' inc
daily exercises are Orthography, Reading, writ
ing, Arithmetic, English Grammar hhe'oric'
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts; Construction of maps; use oi the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry; Elements OF Moral
Science.


ITeekIy Exercises. s.-Biblical Rccitations; Evi'
dences Of Christianity; Letter Writing, and oth
or srccies of Composition; Itecapitulatlons.


1erms.-Board and tuition, in any OF the fore
going branches, s32, so per quarter; or, 1t paid
in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, Sl2, French, by one of the best masters,
&c per quarter Moderate extra charges fol
Drawing and other ornamental branches.


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian. Particular attention IS PAID mol
only to the manners of the young ladies, but IL
their moral and religious instruction. They arc
regularly conducted TO such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools, as their parents and guar
dams approve. Exercise and recreation, being
essential to the preservation of health and o
mental energy, occupy the intervals Of time no
devoted to study. The institution, in all ITS de
partlnents, is conducted in manner which i
is hoped, will meet the cntire appreciation OF it
patrons.


References. Jihnington- Z. W: Gil
bert; Hon. w Hall; Hon Louis MLane: Phita
de'phia--Rev. Dr. Wilson's Rev. DIR Janeway
Mr. William Janvier, Merchant, James G
Thompson, Esq. Professor of Languages, Uni
versity Of Pennsylvania.


March IS, 1927 2o-3m'

AN ACT to refund certain Duties paid upon


Vessels belonging to citizens of Hamburg, and


their Cargoes.


Be it enacted by the Senate and House q
Representatives Of the United States 81 H.
merica in Congress Assrm6fed, hat the
Secretary of the Treasury be, and he is hereby,
authorised to refund the discriminating duties
that were paid in the ports of the United States
between the third of March, eighteen hundred
and fifteen and the thirteenth of November of
the same year, upon any vessel belonging TO cit
izens of the City of IIamburgh, and their Car
goes; and that the same be paid out of any mon
ey in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated


Approved. March, 2, 1927.

AN ACT authorizing the completion and re.


pair of certain Roads in the Territory of Flori-
aa, and for other purposes.
r Be il enacted By the Senate and House of
RehresentatiUes Of the United States Of H.
1erica in Congress assembled, That the
President of the United States be, and he is
hereby, authorized to cause to be opened and re-
paired, in the Territory Of Florida, public road,
known by the name of the Kings road, from the
Georgia line, by St. Augustine, to New Smyrna.


SEC. 2. And be it further enacted, That
the President be, and he is hereby, authorised
TO employ the troops of the United States, sta
toned in Florida, in such manner as he may
think proper, in opening and repairing such
road; and, for defraying the expenses thereof,
the sum of eleven thousand dollars is hereby ap-
propriated.


SEC. 3. .dnd be it further enacted, That
the additional sum Of five thousand dollars be.
md the same is hereby, appropriated for the
completion Of the United States Military road
from Pensacola to ST. Augustine, by the con
suuction ofa bridge across the ST. Sebastain's rv
er, near st. Augustine; and that the further
sum Of six thousand dollars be, and the same is
hereby appropriated, for the purpose of COM
pleting the road from Colerain, in Georgia to
Tampa Bay, in the Territory of Florida, and the
appropriations aforesaid shall be paid out of any
money in the Treasury and not otherwise appro
priated


SEC. A. 1nd be It further enacted, That
ifany part of the above appropriations shall re-
main unexpended, it shall be appropriated tc
opening the communication between Moschetto
sT Halifax and Indian rivers, in the line Of com

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the New-England Farmer.
CIRDIJNC FRUIT TREES.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Eesseudeu-It is curious, but not
entirely novel case, that the discovery of the
effect Of rird,ing fruit trees in forcing them
into early bearing has been recently claimed
as a new achievement, fer an English,
German. and French horticulturist. Yet
in truth, it was as we'll known to the cele.
brated Button as to any modern cultivator


He was induced to make extensive expe-
riments on the decoration of forest trees prior
to their being felled, with view to ascer-
tain the comparative strength and durabill-
sy of timber cut with the bark on, and that
from which the bark had been removed some
years previously to its being felled. lie
found the strength of the wood OF trees
whose bark had been previously removed
year or two before its being cut, much great
er than that of trees felled with the bark on.
And he found. moreover, that trees win
live from one to four years after the whole
bark has been removed. He then tried
pirdkinr of fruit trees, and the following
sketch from his works will show, that he,
n completely and satisfactorily tested the
effects of it, as any modern cultivator has
done. II have made, (says the Comte de
Bufon,) many experiments upon variety
Of fruit trees. 1t is a certain or intAllible
mode of Fastening the period Of bearing,-
They (the girdled trees) blossom sometimes
three weeks before others, and give earlier
fruit, and equally good the first year. have
even had fruit on pear tree from which
had removed not only the bark but all the
SAT- svoed (alburnum) and these premature
fruits were is good as those OF other trees.
have also removed the 7Yhoie bark from
top to bottom of large apple trees and vigo-
rous plumb trees. This operation has de-
stroyed, even after the first year, the small
est of these trees, but the large ones have
sometimes resisted the effects of this bark
ing for two or three years. They were COW
cred earlier than other trees with prodi-
gious quantity of flowers, but the fruit which
succeeded, never ripened, nor even attained
any considerable size.


availed myself (says Buffon) of the expe-
rience, and of the knowledge, which these
various trials afforded me to attempt to
force into fruit trees of vigorous growth
which seemed to throw all their force


into the production of wood made my
first experiment on ounce tree re-
moved the bark in a spiral form from tive
branches of this tree. These two branches
alone gave fruit---the others remained bar
rem. Instead of removing the bark, some
times simply tied cord round a branch
the effect was the same, had the pleasure
of gathering the fruits of trees which hat
been long barren.


In what manner soever you interrupt ol
intercept the sap, you are sure OF Fastening
production of fruits, and especially of flow
ers."

full articles.headline:
LAWS OF TEE UNIoN.

by AUTHORITY.
full articles.article:
PASSED AT THE SECOND SESSION OF


THE NINETEENTH CONGRESS,

The introduction OF the potatoe plant into
France, received, for more than two ccntu-
rles, an unexampled opposition from vulgar
prejudice; and it wasnot until Louis XIV who
wore branch Of the flowers of the potatoe
in the midst of the court, on day of testiv-
ity, that the people for the first time yielded
through fashion to acknowledge its value.

Tobacco & Segar Manufacturers
Thomas A. Starret, lo7high st.

Tohrese,7e Potatoes.---Mr. Roberts has
taken out patent tor the following method
of keeping potatoes, carrots, and other veg
ctables, in the warmest climates for con-
siderable time:


"Take the potatoes, or other vegetables,
when thoroughly ripe, and before they have
grown In the spring, cut out with kniie
the germs or eyes, or destroy them. The
more they are kept from the air, the finer
they will be.
